description.narrative: 1. Availability of modernized infrastructure of BCPs, including provision of fixed-placed equipment. 2. Availability of capacity of border management agencies on application of new procedures and use of the provided equipment/IT systems. 5. Availability of short time for border crossing for passengers.

comment.narrative: 1. Border Crossing Points (BCP) in Bagrastshen, Bavra and Gogavan are not modernized (2012). 2. Off-the-site gas-supply, power-supply and fiber-optics networks in Gogavan BCP are not available (2012). 3. Portable equipment and IT systems in Bagrastshen, Bavra and Gogavan BCPs are not available (2012). 4. Capacities of border management agencies on application of new procedures and use of the provided equipment/IT systems is not available and to be developed (2012). 5. The time for border crossing for passengers is long; to be reduced (2012).

description.narrative: Energy - power generation

1.1. Availability of methodology for energy/lighting audit 1.2. Availability of outputs of conducted energy audits for the municipal lighting systems of all the urban areas/cities that had officially applied and requested those 1.3. Availability of consistent and continuous training for specialists and agency representatives both as officially requested and within the thematic events 1.4. Level of the project's public outreach/media exposure 2.1. Level of upgrade in efficiency and energy savings of installed energy efficient lighting in selected buildings 2.2. Level of upgrade in the share of light-emitting diodes in demo-projects 3.1. Availability of developed municipal programs for energy efficient public lighting 3.2. Availability of confirmed financial commitments for energy-efficient municipal lighting 4.1. Availability of developed regulations that mandate improved energy efficiency of lighting products and installations

comment.narrative: 1.1. Lack of methodology for assessing energy efficiency in lighting (2013) 1.2. Municipalities are not aware of energy saving potential in lighting sector (2013) 1.3. No specialized training or training materials on energy efficient lighting is offered in Armenia (2013) 1.4. Limited broadcasting of information on energy efficient lighting (2013) 2.1. The majority of fixtures in municipal street lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250 Watt high-pressure sodium lamps or 400 Watt mercury-vapor lamps (2013) 2.2. The majority of fixtures in municipal street lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250 Watt high-pressure sodium lamps or 400 Watt mercury-vapor lamps (2013) 3.1. Municipal programs for energy efficient public lighting are desired but not comprehensively designed, financed, or implemented (2013) 3.2. Municipal programs for energy efficient public lighting are desired but not comprehensively designed, financed, or implemented (2013) 4.1. There is no regulation on energy performance of lighting products in Armenia (2013)

1.1. A municipal lighting energy audit methodology manual, as developed and tested by the Project, applied in the course of the energy audits. 1.2. Five public (municipal) lighting system audited, target municipality informed respectively, results processed for further use within Demonstration and Financial Components of the Project. 1.3. Training and capacity building materials on energy efficient lighting developed. 1.4. Awareness raising materials available for general public. 2.1. Baseline energy consumption of the pilot projects assessed and resulting energy saving of the pilot lighting systems measured. 2.2. Light-emitting diodes efficiency requirements applied in street lighting pilot projects increased up to 100 lumen/W. 3.1. Interested municipalities supported in development and implementation of municipal lighting upgrade programs. 3.2. Financial mechanisms established for replication the pilot projects for four municipalities. 4.1. Relevant legislation and standards and norms drafted and discussed considering harmonization with EurAsEC requirements.

1.1. The methodology applied within energy audit in Ararat, Abovyan, Sevan, Kapan, Kajaran, Gavar and Stepanavan towns. 1.2. Audits in Ararat, Sevan, Kapan, Kajaran, Gavar and Stepanavan towns conducted and reports produced. 1.3. Educational module for college students on light and issues and energy efficient technologies and solutions in the sector were developed and presentations delivered for about 180 college students in 5 institutions. International Consultant lead a workshop for about 20 specialists on design and implementation of energy efficient lighting of road tunnels. Seminar on modern lighting, lighting norms and standards, measuring equipment was held for about 50 representatives of state authorities of the RA, design institutions, private sector, educational institutions and academia. A brief guide for high school students on existing lighting technologies, their application, pros and cons, modern energy efficient solutions was prepared. The established optoelectronic testing laboratory was equipped with integral sphere and other devices and so far 24 light units were tested. 1.4. Green procurement manual developed and submitted to the RA Government for approval and enactment. Awareness raising materials prepared and shared via the project's web-site as well as broadcasted via television. A documentary movie on street lighting systems and project outcomes is broadcasted. For each demonstration project, a fact-sheet is prepared. Guidelines on lighting system installation in tunnels were prepared, published and distributed. 2.1. The baseline energy consumption assessed for Yerevan city's expanded pilot and for pilots in Ararat, Abovyan and Sevan towns. The measurements conducted for the installed fixtures for pilot project in Kapan town. Indoor lighting upgrade projects are implemented: i) in “Mush” child development center in cooperation with World Vision, ii) in social building in Yerevan in cooperation with Ministry of Labor and Social Affair

1.1. To expand application of lighting system energy audit methodology to more urban areas (indoor and outdoor). 1.2. Four public (municipal) lighting systems audited, target municipality informed respectively, results processed for further use within Demonstration and Financial Components of the Project. 1.3. Training and capacity building materials on energy efficient lighting developed. 1.4. Awareness raising materials available for general public. 2.1. Baseline energy consumption of the pilot projects assessed and resulting energy saving of the pilot lighting systems measured. 2.2. Light-emitting diodes efficiency requirements applied in street lighting pilot projects increased up to 100 lumen/W. 3.1. Interested municipalities supported in development and implementation of municipal lighting upgrade programs. 3.2. Financial mechanisms established for replication the pilot projects for four municipalities. 4.1. Harmonized "Artificial and Natural Lighting" RACN 22-03-2017 approved and enacted, and further shared with the stakeholders.

1.1. The methodology applied within energy audit in Yerevan city indoor demo projects and in Tashir, Talin, Masis, Meghri, Dilijan, Akhtala, Vanadzor cities' outdoor demo projects. 1.2. For the cities mentioned in point 1.1 above, the energy audits completed and reports produced. 1.3. (i) The established optoelectronic testing laboratory was equipped with integral sphere and other devices and so far 71 light units were tested; (ii) Seven educational modules to be incorporated in the profile universities’ curricula are completed in Armenian and in English and are in the stage of publication preparation, (iii) The UN Geneva Charter on Sustainable Housing was translated into Armenian, consulted with State Committee of Urban Development and published, (iv) In partnership with National Institute of Standards, "World Standards Day" was celebrated in Armenia with informational events and award ceremonies for energy efficiency pioneering accomplishments, (v) The project held "Energy Saving by Energy Management" training for municipalities on basics of energy management, design features of modern lighting systems, and green procurement opportunities, (vi) Two seminars on methods and techniques for upgrading street lighting systems were organized for select target audiences, (vii) The demonstration stands on different lighting devices and thematic posters were designed, produced and provided to profile universities as practical illustrative tools for lighting energy efficiency related subjects. 1.4. (i) Green procurement manual further circulated in the RA Government for approval and enactment, (ii) In partnership with the Yerevan city municipality, a series of events, including seminars, flash mobs and informational campaign, were held under "Green Lighting Week" umbrella, (iii) Project achievements were summarized in an article published by "Architecture and Construction" specialized journal, (iv) Awareness raising materials prepared and shared via the project's web-sit

1. Revision of the road construction norm's lighting section. 2. Monitoring of the demo projects and supporting the municipalities in planning the extension works. 3. Continuing support to the testing of luminaries and lamps in the laboratory. 4. Support the design institutions in applying new construction norms for proper light design for schools and kindergartens. 5. Launch the new publication "Green Lighting" bilingual textbook, conducting open lessons in the two profile universities and distribution of the textbook to laboratories and users. 6. Selection of the Independent Technical Evaluator for conducting project's terminal evaluation to be completed by June 2018. 7. Lessons learned report prepared and distributed by a month before the end of the project. 8. Trainings, seminars, awareness campaigns, including two-day retreat/training on Scaling the Energy Efficiency in lighting sector for municipalities representatives.

description.narrative: To remove barriers to energyefficient lighting in Armenia by means of technical assessment facilitation of financing and development and implementation of municipal programs and national policy
Quantity of energy saved and GHG emissions avoided

comment.narrative:
Street lighting 40 GWh of electricity consumed for street lighting in 2011 accounting for about 16000 tons of CO2 emissions
Average fixture power consumption is 210W in 2011
Residential lighting 550 GWh consumed for residential lighting in 2011 accounting for about 220000 tons of CO2 emissions

Direct energy savings of 12 GWh per year from demonstration projects 474 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy savings of 20 GWh per year from replication of demonstration projects via municipal programs 8000 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy savings of 125 GWh per year from implementation of national lighting policy 50000 tonnes of CO2 emissions

Direct energy savings achieved within the reporting period from demonstration projects is 1276 MWh 91 and 566 tonnes of CO2 emissions
Indirect energy saving from replication of demonstration projects is expected to be achieved within the next reporting period
Indirect energy saving from implementation of national lighting policy is expected to be achieved by the end of the project

description.narrative: Demonstration projects Pilot projects yield costeffective energy savings raising the confidence and capacity of investors and decisionmakers about EE lighting

Efficiency and energy savings of installed EE lighting
Share of LED in demoprojects

comment.narrative:
The majority of fixtures in municipal outdoor lighting sector incorporate inefficient 250W HPS lamps or 400W mercuryvapor lamps
The indoor lighting sector is dominated by inefficient incandescent lamps and fluorescent tubes

At least five demonstration projects on a number of efficient lighting technologies completed for indoor outdoor and street lighting
Direct energy savings of up to 095 GWh per year by completion of all pilots subject to final selection of pilot size and technologies 100 LED for outdoor park and indoor lighting pilots 40 LED included in street lighting pilots

3 demonstration projects are completed
In Yerevan 482 street LED luminaires were procured and installed on the road connecting the citys center with Zvartnots international airport 9 km replacing high pressure sodium lamps with 63 energy efficiency improvement
In Yerevan Zoological Garden 115 park LED luminaires were procured and installed as a part of full reconstruction of the lighting system
In Alaverdi 70 street LED were installed with 55 procured by the project and 15 by the partner NGO FrenchArmenian interprofessional network
100 LED replacement is achieved in all the three implemented demonstration projects

Number of municipal energy audits conducted

Public media exposure

comment.narrative:
Lack of methodology for assessing the feasibility financial and technical of an energy efficient lighting technology upgrade
Comprehensive energy audits are not part of normal practice for public lighting in Armenia
No specialized training on EE lighting is offered in Armenia
Limited broadcasting of information on EE lighting

By the project midterm the methodology will be established and shared with municipalities
At least 10 comprehensive audits of public lighting completed in Yerevan and other cities
Training on EE lighting delivered to specialists and agency representatives in Yerevan and at least 10 other cities
Media releases on outcomes of each pilot Awareness raising materials available for general public

The methodology was developed and tested during energy audit in Yerevan city demo site Alaverdi Stepanavan Spitak and Goris towns Total 5 audits
30 specialists were trained of Yerevan Municipal Illumination Company and respective municipalities on proper installation and operation and maintenance of lightemitting diodes LED luminaires
Seminar on technical regulation of lighting devices application and establishment of national testing laboratory was held by a specialists of a partner to the project Center of LED and optoelectronic technologies of National Academy of Sciences of Belarus 50 participants
Awareness raising materials prepared and disseminated including sharing during relevant events

description.narrative: National policies codes and standards on lighting New national policies mandate significantly greater energy efficiency and ensure product quality for lighting particularly in residential buildings
Existence of regulations that mandate improved energy efficiency of lighting products and installations including codes standards and procurement rules

comment.narrative:
Conventional incandescent lighting is available without restrictions and constitutes 85 percent of residential lighting in Armenia
There is no regulation on energy performance of lighting products in Armenia

Proposed improvement to existing legislation addressing minimum energy performance requirements for lighting appliances
A national phaseout plan of conventional incandescent lighting is adopted
Other adopted policies and supporting standards
New criteria including performance and life cycle costs for incorporation in state procurement procedures for lighting applications are developed

The energy labeling procedure economy sector identification by its energyintensity concept for further use in statistics and a number of other amendments after discussion were included in the amendments to the RA Law On Renewable Energy and Energy Saving currently pending adoption by the National Assembly of the RA
The decision of RA Government as developed by the project On implementation of energy saving and energy efficiency improvement measures in objects being constructed reconstructed renovated under the state funding was approved by the Government of the RA decision 1504N of December 25 2014
International experience on phaseout of inefficient incandescent lamps was studied and a respective analytical note was elaborated including an address to legal and regulatory issues

Similar programs are adopted in other cities of Armenia

US 10 million for energyefficient municipal lighting secured
Establishment of financing mechanisms for Yerevan and other municipalities eg revolving fund from savings achieved from piloted EE measures
Support in preparation of funding proposals including tenders for ESCOs for cities of Armenia

Municipal programs for Alaverdi Spitak Goris and Stepanavan towns are drafted Alaverdi and Spitak drafts are shared with the owner municipalities for comments and further approval
Revolving fund concept operation procedure and financial flow estimation methodology are developed discussed approved and at work in Yerevan In Alaverdi the revolving fund concept is under consideration

description.narrative: Generate global environmental benefits through environmental education and raising awareness of stakeholders
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Project implementation office

description.narrative: Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Availability of key policies for EE in place integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ obligations 2. Availability of conducive legislation framework to support EE as a tool for NRM 3. Availability of institutions with clear mandate to implement EE programmes 4. Availability of key strategies and programmes integrating EE, as well as Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ obligations, as a tool to address NRM issues and solutions 5. Number of key stakeholders in different organizations trained to deliver EE programmes with a minimum of 40% women 6. Availability of EE programmes and delivery mechanisms to public servants and practicing teachers 7. Number of people trained (civil servants and teachers) with a minimum of 40% women 8. Level of use of EE as a tool to make communities environmentally aware and to involve them in addressing NRM issues by the NGOs, CBOs and local governments 9. Availability of EE programmes delivered by strengthened delivery mechanisms

comment.narrative: 1.Current policies are poorly known, weakly implemented and do not include environmental education (EE) as an effective tool to address natural resource management (NRM) issues (2015). 2. Current Law on EE, and related laws are not conducive to the use of EE as a tool for NRM (2015). 3. Weak institutional mandates, weak national coordination and unclear responsibilities for EE (2015). 4. Current strategies and programmes do not include EE as a tool to address NRM issues (2015). 5. Few key stakeholders are trained to develop and deliver EE programmes in Armenia (2015). 6. Limited training materials on EE and delivery mechanisms targeting civil servants and practicing teachers (2015). 7. Limited number of EE trainings offered (2015). 8. NGOs, CBOs and local governments use very little EE techniques (2015). 9. Numerous materials on EE exist in Armenia but there is no common approach to deliver EE covering global environmental issues and solutions (2015).

1. Analysis of policies for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements conducted 2. Analysis of legislative framework to support EE as a tool for NRM conducted 3. Institutional analysis conducted 4. Analysis of policies for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements conducted 5. Not applicable for 2016 6. EE programmes and trainings delivery mechanisms studied 7. 0 8. Not applicable for 2016 9. Not applicable for 2016

1. Analysis of policies for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements conducted 2. Analysis of legislative framework to support EE as a tool for NRM conducted 3. Institutional analysis conducted 4. Analysis of policies for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements conducted 5. Not applicable for 2016 6. EE programmes and trainings delivery mechanisms for decision makers studied 7. 0 8. Not applicable for 2016 9. Not applicable for 2016

1. Policy instruments/amendments for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements identified and respective recommendations developed 2. Legal instruments/amendments for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements identified and respective recommendations developed 3. Action plan to address prioritized institutional gaps to integrate EE and public awareness developed 4. Key strategies, programmes and projects integrating EE and public awareness developed 5. Not applicable for Y2017 6. EE programmes and trainings delivery mechanisms for decision makers scoped 7. Not applicable for Y2017 8. CBOs’ capacities in the area of EE and public awareness identified and recommendations for capacity building developed 9. EE materials and delivery mechanisms for CBOs scoped

1. Policies for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements identified, recommendations developed and incorporated in the draft National Strategy on Environmental Education. 2. Legal instruments/amendments for EE integrating Rio and Aarhus Conventions’ requirements identified, recommendations developed and incorporated in the draft National Strategy on Environmental Education. 3. Institutional analysis conducted and incorporated in the draft National Strategy on Environmental Education. 4. Draft National Strategy on Environmental Education is developed. 5. Not applicable for Y2017. Indicator is for 2018 6. Training Need Analysis for governmental sector staff conducted, recommendations developed. Draft training package is developed. 7. Not applicable for Y2017. Indicator is for 2018 8. Community based organizations (CBO) capacities and needs assessed, recommendations developed. 9. Draft EE materials and delivery mechanisms for CBOs developed.

1. Implementation of the of Rio and Aarhus convention in Armenia promoted through law enforcement and awareness raising activities, as well as development new dissemination platform/tools and materials (websites, animation films etc.). 2. Package on legal and and/or policy instruments/amendments supporting EE as a tool for NRM is developed and presented for approval by the Government of the Republic of Armenia. 3. The EE curricula for civil and community servants is approved by Civil Service Council and Ministry of Territorial Administration and Development. The "National Strategy on development of Ecological Education and Upbringing" is approved by the Government of RA. The draft package of documents to mainstream environmental education into national development strategies and programmes is developed and presented for approval of the Government of RA. 4. The capacity of 50 teachers to conduct EE is developed through organized Training of Trainers workshops and providing methodological manuals and syllabuses. 5. The training materials, including digital educational materials, on environmental education materials are developed, published or produced. The educational entitles to deliver EE courses for civil and community servants are selected through selection process approved by Government. 6. Support the delivery EE courses for civil and community servant are conducted by educational entitles such as public Administration Academy of RA. 7. The capacities of CBO staff and journalists are developed via training and workshops and by support to delivery of EE projects and public awareness campaigns. 8. Increased awareness and advocacy about environmental issues through media, formal and non-formal trainings.

comment.narrative: 1.1. No Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) systems for the buildings sector in Armenia established. 1.2. No knowledge management and MRV information disseminated. 2.1. Framework not used for energy efficiency in Armenia. 2.2. Policies proposed and consultation ongoing. 2.3. Secondary legislation lacking. 2.4. No business models for repayment of energy efficiency investments in buildings in place. 2.5. No exit strategy measures implemented 3.1. Banks do not have the capacity to develop and market products for energy efficiency retrofits in individual houses. 3.2. Banks do not have the capacity to develop and market products for energy efficiency retrofits in multi-owner residential buildings. 3.3. Local government does not have the capacity to develop energy efficiency retrofit projects for publicly-owned buildings. 3.4. No lending provided. 3.5. No marketing materials exist. 4.1.
